During my career as a law enforcement officer I was fortunate enough to teach DARE drug education in schools. In DARE we delve into stress and "fight or flight" response while covering why some people use drugs.
I used to equate stress to friction during these lessons. I would tell the students that like stress, some friction is necessary for life to "move along", giving an example of a car tire on a roadway. Not enough stress or friction, like ice on that roadway causes its own specific problems yet too much stress or friction also has its specific pitfalls. (This is the readers digest version on my lesson plans) I would end up having the students put their hands together, palm to palm and have them rub these together adding more and more pressure as they went for a physical example of friction. Even though rudimentary, this lesson really helped get the point across.
